The possibility to detect and quantify industrial smoke plumes from globally available multi-band image data from ESA's Sentinel-2 satellites has been explored. Using a modified ResNet-50 model, we can detect smoke plumes of different sizes with an accuracy of 94.3%. The model correctly ignores natural clouds and focuses on imaging channels related to spectral absorption from aerosols and water vapor, enabling the localization of smoke. We exploit this localization ability and train a U-Net segmentation model on a labeled sub-sample of our data, resulting in an Intersection-over-Union (IoU) metric of 0.608 and an overall accuracy for the detection of any smoke plume of 94.0%. On average, our model can reproduce the area covered by smoke in an image to within 5.6%.

Our results enable us to reliably detect and qualitatively estimate the level of smoke activity to monitor industrial plants across the globe. However, the performance of our model is limited by occasional confusion with surface objects, the inability to identify semi-transparent smoke, and human limitations in identifying smoke based on RGB-only images.

Global warming poses a significant threat to social and economic stability. Most observed climate changes are driven by human activities, primarily the consumption of fossil fuels, leading to rising levels of atmospheric CO2 and other greenhouse gases. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is essential to limit long-term damage to the climate. Monitoring greenhouse gas emissions globally would allow us to understand its effects and enforce environmental protection measures.

However, direct measurement of greenhouse gas emissions is expensive, especially on a large scale, and legal requirements to report industrial emissions vary significantly. A method to globally quantify industrial emissions would improve our understanding of greenhouse gas emissions, enable systematic monitoring, and inform policymakers.

This work investigates the possibility of using industrial smoke plumes based on satellite imagery as a proxy to quantify greenhouse gas emissions. The goal is to establish a pipeline to monitor the state and level of activity of industrial plants using remote sensing data to estimate their greenhouse gas emissions in combination with environmental data.

Our contribution to climate change monitoring is threefold: (1) we compiled a large-scale annotated dataset of active industrial sites with additional segmentation masks for a subset of these smoke plumes, (2) we presented a modified ResNet-50 approach to detect active smoke plumes with an accuracy of 94.3%, and (3) we utilized a U-Net approach to segment smoke plumes and measure their areal projections on average within 5.6% of human manual annotations.

The detection of smoke from remote sensing imaging data has been mostly restricted to identifying wildfires. A common method uses multi-thresholding of multi-spectral imaging data, exploiting the spectral characteristics of smoke plumes. With the rise of machine learning, supervised and unsupervised learning methods have been implemented to automatically detect wildfires and their smoke plumes. Other efforts use physical dispersion or statistical models or ground-based observations from consumer-grade camera systems in combination with algorithmic solutions or deep learning approaches. However, these methods are limited in their ability to monitor large areas and require individual deployment for each site. Multi-spectral observations from space can monitor large areas.
